value.title: Moving Fast with Dart Immutable Values

content.subtitle: Dart’s built_value provides powerful, convenient immutable values for Dart. The values might be immutable, but the package hasn’t been…

paragraphs.name: fd52
paragraphs.text: Moving Fast with Dart Immutable Values

Dart’s built_value provides powerful, convenient immutable values for Dart. The values might be immutable, but the package hasn’t been standing still! In the six months since I last wrote about built_value there have been ten major improvements to the package.

paragraphs.name: d003
paragraphs.text: I also spotted some interesting uses of built_value in the Dart community:

paragraphs.name: 929c
paragraphs.text: The built_redux package is a redux-inspired package using built_value. It comes with bindings and examples for flutter, angular2 and react-dart.

paragraphs.name: 89f6
paragraphs.text: The built_highcharts package is a highcharts wrapper using built_value. The demo is really rather nice.

paragraphs.name: 123f
paragraphs.text: And, here’s another way of using built_value with Flutter.

paragraphs.name: b113
paragraphs.text: Anyway, without further ado, here are all the great new things in built_value.

paragraphs.name: dc77
paragraphs.text: 1. Generic classes

paragraphs.name: 394d
paragraphs.text: Sophisticated object models use generics, so of course built_value needs generics. You can now declare your type using generics and the generated builder class will also support them:

paragraphs.name: 31da

paragraphs.text: var value = new GenericValue<String>((b) => b..value = 'string');

paragraphs.name: cf30
paragraphs.text: Value types using generics are serializable, as usual.

paragraphs.name: a145
paragraphs.text: 2. Serializer plugins

paragraphs.name: ab1c
paragraphs.text: A new SerializerPlugin API allows you to make cross-cutting modifications to serialization, by running arbitrary code before and after every object is serialized or deserialized.

paragraphs.name: 00d8
paragraphs.text: You could, for example, use this to map between two wire-incompatible versions of a protocol. But a better example is the next improvement…

paragraphs.name: 958b
paragraphs.text: 3. “Standard JSON” serializer plugin

paragraphs.name: 3c7b
paragraphs.text: By default, built_value serializes to and from its own list-based JSON format, for performance and flexibility.

paragraphs.name: 651e
paragraphs.text: But many people need to inter-operate with existing JSON data and APIs. What should they do?

paragraphs.name: a56b
paragraphs.text: Now, you can install StandardJsonPlugin and switch to a standard map-based JSON format.

paragraphs.name: b556
paragraphs.text: See the example (towards the end).

paragraphs.name: 77b7
paragraphs.text: 4. Getter memoization

Immutable classes are great — but what should you do about derived fields? If a derived field is expensive to compute, then immutable classes give two bad options: computing them upfront and always paying a possibly unnecessary penalty, or recomputing them on demand and potentially paying that same large cost many times.

paragraphs.name: 4d74
paragraphs.text: Enter @memoized getters. Add this annotation to a built_value getter and it will be calculated lazily, but at most once; it’s then stored in a hidden field on the instance.

paragraphs.name: 5fc0
paragraphs.text: Since 1.1.2 built_value itself is a great example of @memoized getters. A built_value is used to wrap an Element from the analyzer, and computation is done lazily in getters:

paragraphs.name: 00be
8da2
ee4c
paragraphs.text:
// And many more @memoized getters.
}

paragraphs.name: 36a8
paragraphs.text: 5. Faster code generation
…and as a result of moving to memoized getters, built_value is now significantly faster at generating code.
6. Simpler factories

paragraphs.name: 099e
paragraphs.text: Prior to 0.5.5 every built_value class had to have a factory method following a standard template. This requirement has been relaxed. Here are a few good ways to use this greater freedom.

paragraphs.name: aa3f
paragraphs.text: For classes with one or two fields, just take exactly those fields in the constructor:

paragraphs.name: fc83
paragraphs.text:
abstract class Value implements Built<Value, ValueBuilder> {
  ClassElement get element;

paragraphs.name: d03c
442e
paragraphs.text: Or, where you want to set defaults for fields, you can now do this in the factory, instead of having to write your own builder class:

paragraphs.name: d019
78fb
d9fb
paragraphs.text: Finally, if you like named arguments, you can expose the named-argument-based constructor instead of the builder-based constructor:

paragraphs.name: a12a

paragraphs.text: factory Value({int x, int y}) = _$Value._;

paragraphs.name: d433

paragraphs.text: 7. Prettier and customizable toString output

paragraphs.name: bd2c
paragraphs.text: Before 1.0.0 built_value’s toString output was rather flat. Now, by default it’s indended, so it’s easy to read:

paragraphs.name: b754
84bf
paragraphs.text: But, it’s also customizable, via a top-level global variable newBuiltValueToStringHelper. If you preferred the old format:

newBuiltValueToStringHelper =
    (className) => new FlatBuiltValueToStringHelper(className);

paragraphs.name: d34f
paragraphs.text: Then:

paragraphs.name: 2a17
paragraphs.text: CompoundValue {simpleValue=SimpleValue {anInt=1}}

paragraphs.name: cc2a
paragraphs.text: And if you want to write your own — of course you can. The BuiltValueToStringHelper class is very easy to implement:

paragraphs.name: c395
e9ba
paragraphs.text: 8. Serializable DateTime and JsonObject

paragraphs.name: b68a
paragraphs.text: The SDKDateTime class is now serializable — provided you use UTC rather than local time zone. (Serializing with local time zone is a recipe for disaster!)

paragraphs.name: 2c18
paragraphs.text: And, to help further with interop with existing JSON data and APIs, there is now a JsonObject class that wraps json values, lists and maps. Fields of type JsonObject serialize directly to and from raw JSON.

paragraphs.name: 9f00
paragraphs.text: 9. Custom matcher for tests

paragraphs.name: de71
paragraphs.text: The generated operator== methods in built_value are already very handy for tests, but there’s one thing they don’t give you: easily readable error messages. Instead, when an ‘equals’ check in a test fails, you’ll get the full toString of the expected and actual values.

paragraphs.name: 997c
paragraphs.text: Not any more! You can now use built_value_test, a new pub package. If you use it in a test you’ll now see errors like this:

paragraphs.name: 72df
paragraphs.text: was <3> instead of <5> at location ['simpleValue']['anInt']

paragraphs.name: c736
paragraphs.text: If this looks a lot like the message you get when a map compare fails in a test, that’s because it’s the same: it’s implemented by converting the values to maps then comparing.

paragraphs.name: 1c8f
paragraphs.text: 10. Implicit-dynamic and implicit-cast friendly code; better error messages

paragraphs.name: ad43
paragraphs.text: The code generated by built_value has been cleaned up significantly to make it pass two very strict lints: it no longer uses dynamic implicitly anywhere, and it no longer relies on implicit casts.

paragraphs.name: f396
paragraphs.text: These two improvements may (or may not) lead to better code from the compiler.

paragraphs.name: 35af
paragraphs.text: And, better error messages were added for when you declare a serializer field with the wrong type.

paragraphs.name: dddc
paragraphs.text: That was it! Thanks for reading. If you have any ideas or feature requests for built_value, head on over to the issue tracker.
